newsitem.title: UK: Tories' "Demon Eyes" poster wins UK ad award.
newsitem.headline: Tories' "Demon Eyes" poster wins UK ad award.

text.p: The controversial "Demon Eyes" poster advertisement unveiled by Britain's Conservative Party last summer on Thursday was named the top ad campaign for 1996 by a UK trade publication.
Campaign magazine said it named the Tories' poster ad -- which portrayed rival Labour leader Tony Blair with demonic red eyes and a manic grin peering through net curtains -- as Campaign of the Year.

Campaign editor Stefano Hatfield said the magazine's heavily pro-Labour Party staff itself found the decision quite controversial, but put personal prejudices aside in recognition of the ad's effectiveness.
"Unquestionably this campaign worked," Hatfield told Reuters in a phone interview.
"Even the Labour Party privately admitted last year that the Conservatives had blown them out of the water," Hatfield said.

The ad, designed by long-time Conservative Party advertising gurus Maurice and Charles Saatchi, cost about 125,000 to 150,000 pounds, but generated about five million pounds in free publicity, Hatfield said.
In addition, not only did the media report on the ad itself, but opened the debate sparked by the ad's "New Labour, New Danger" theme of whether Labour can be trusted, he said.
The ad sparked a storm of criticism when it debuted in August, drawing fire from church leaders, newspaper writers and even some Conservative members of Parliament.

A survey published in October by a market research group found that the ad was more well-remembered than the Labour Party's "Same Old Tories, Same Old Lies" ad run in the same period, but that people liked the Labour Party ad better.
Campaign's Hatfield, however, said that the lack of recall for the Labour Party ad highlighted its weakness.
"The great trick for the Saatchis for the Conservatives is people remember the ads," he said. "You don't remember the Labour Party ads."
But Hatfield said the new advertising campaign unveiled by the Conservatives earlier this week is disappointing. "The new one is very disappointing. It's not based on any truths," he said.
